   Work period of Police Department, see  §
34.03
§ 32.003  UNIFORM AND EQUIPMENT ACQUISITION.
   Each full time police officer, after completion of every calendar year of
full time service, shall in January of each successive year receive $500 for
the officer’s purchase of uniform items and/or equipment. Each part time police
officer, for completion of 520 hours of service in any calendar year, shall
thereafter in that same calendar year and upon the Police Chief’s written
approval, receive $100 for the officer’s purchase of uniform and/or equipment.
The Village Fiscal Officer shall make each expenditure upon the written
approval of the Chief of Police.
(`94 Code, § 145.04)  (Ord. 10-81, passed 2-26-81; Am. Ord. 19-97, passed 6-10-
97; Am. Ord. 4-2001, passed 2-13-01; Am. Ord. 15-2011, passed 4-26-11; Am. Ord.
2-2012, passed 2-14-12)
§ 32.004  RESERVED.
§ 32.005  LIABILITY AND FALSE ARREST INSURANCE.
   The Chief of Police and all patrolmen Classes I, II and III shall maintain
liability and false arrest insurance. The Chief and Classes I and III patrolmen
shall maintain such insurance at the high-hazard rate and patrolmen of Class
III shall maintain such insurance at the medium rate. All premiums due and
payable upon such insurance contracts shall be paid by the village from the
General Fund-Safety Division.
(`94 Code, § 145.07)  (Ord. 10-81, passed 2-26-81)
§ 32.006  BENEFITS.
   The Chief of Police and Class II patrolmen shall be entitled to paid medical
insurance, life insurance, sick leave, paid holidays and paid vacation in
accordance with
Chapter 34. Class III patrolmen shall not be entitled to such benefits except
as otherwise set forth in this chapter or in
Chapter 34. The Chief of Police and Class II patrolmen shall also be subject to
the provisions of §§
34.05 and
34.09 through
34.12.
(`94 Code, § 145.08)  (Ord. 10-81, passed 2-26-81)
§ 32.007  AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE.
   (A)   Creation; appointment; members.
      (1)   There is created an Auxiliary Police Force, consisting of special
policemen to be known as Auxiliary Policemen.
      (2)   At no time shall the membership of such Auxiliary Police Force
exceed 50 members.
   (B)   Service.  Auxiliary Police shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor or
until their resignation shall have been accepted by the Mayor.
   (C)   Qualifications; age and residency.  Members of the Auxiliary Police
Force shall reside within 100 miles of the Plymouth Municipal Building and
shall not be less than 21 years of age at the time of their appointment.
   (D)   Commanding Officer.  The Chief of Police shall be the Commanding
Officer of the Auxiliary Police Force and shall have control of the assigning,
training, stationing, and working of such Force.
   (E)   Powers.  Auxiliary Police, when so acting and when in the prescribed
uniform, shall have all police powers of the ordinary members of the Police
Force. They shall obey the orders given to them by the Chief of Police and any
chain of command in the Police Department that he or she may designate.
   (F)   Rules and regulations.  The Mayor shall prescribe the rules and
regulations for the conduct and control of the Auxiliary Police Force. He shall
prescribe the uniform, badge, or other designation to be used by such Force. No
member of such Force shall be assigned or sent on any assignment outside the
Municipality.
(Ord. 24-2008, passed 6-10-08)
VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ 32.020  REIMBURSEMENT OF FIRE AND EMT TRAINING EXPENSES.
   No person shall receive fire and/or EMT training, at the expense of the
village, unless the person shall first agree, in writing, to reimburse the
village, on a pro rata basis, for the cost of the training, in the event such
person serves the village in such capacities for a period of less than two
years. Such costs as are reimbursable shall include the fire school costs and
materials and the Basic EMT School costs and materials.
(Ord. 39-2000, passed 11-28-00)
§ 32.021  ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION; AMBULANCE DIVISION.
   (A)   There is hereby established in and for the village a Fire Department,
to be composed of a Fire Chief and such other officers and personnel as Council
shall, from time to time, determine.
(`94 Code, § 147.01)
   (B)   Ambulance division.
      (1)   That agency of government formerly known as the Ambulance
Department is hereby merged into the Volunteer Fire Department and shall
hereafter be operated by the Fire Department as a separate Division within such
Department and shall be under control of its officers, subject to the mandate
of the Mayor and Council.
      (2)   Any and all moneys standing in the former Ambulance Department
account with the village shall be transferred to the Fire Department, but shall
be maintained by the Village Fiscal Officer in separate accounts distinctly
marked.
(`94 Code, § 147.02)  (Ord. 2-84, passed 1-10-84)
§ 32.022  COMPOSITION AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF OFFICERS; COMPENSATION.
   (A)   Officers.
      (1)   There is hereby created within the Fire Department the following
positions and respective order of command and responsibility:
         (a)   A Fire Chief who shall be the head of both the Fire Department
and the Ambulance Division of the Fire Department;
         (b)   Up to three Assistant Chiefs who shall be second in command of
the Fire Department and the Ambulance Division;
         (c)   Up to three Captains who shall be third in command of the Fire
Department and the Ambulance Division; and
         (d)   Up to three Lieutenants who shall be fourth in command of the
Fire Department and the Ambulance Division.
      (2)   Each of the above positions and any vacancy occurring therein shall
be filled by appointment by the Mayor upon recommendation of the Fire Chief.
Each appointment shall be approved and confirmed by a majority vote of the
members of Council.
      (3)   The incumbent of each of the above positions shall be paid an
annual salary from the operation and maintenance of funds of the Fire
Department and Ambulance Division, on a pro rata basis, in accordance with the
pay ordinance then in effect. Payments shall be made in equal monthly
installments.
   (B)   Firefighters/emergency medical technicians, drivers and dispatchers.
Firefighters/emergency medical technicians, firefighters/paramedics, drivers
and dispatchers responding to calls shall be members of the Village Fire
Department. Members of the Department may be volunteers or paid part- time
village employees. Job descriptions for each position shall be maintained by
the Fire Chief.
   (C)   Compensation.
      (1)   Members of the Fire Department who meet the qualifications set
forth by Council may perform services in both the Fire and Ambulance Divisions,
but shall be paid at the rate prescribed by the ordinance for the division in
which the services are performed.
      (2)   Firefighters/emergency medical technicians, firefighters/
paramedics, drivers and dispatchers shall be compensated as provided, in
accordance with the pay ordinance then in effect by Council, payable from the
Ambulance Operation and Maintenance Fund.
      (3)   The compensation of volunteer firefighters shall be determined,
from time to time, by Council, and shall be payable monthly from the Fire
Operation and Maintenance Fund. The compensation of firefighter/EMT's who work
scheduled part-time shifts shall be determined, from time to time, by Council,
and shall be payable from the respective departments Operations and Maintenance
Fund on a bi-weekly basis.
(Ord. 7-2021, passed 4-13-21)
§ 32.023  USE OF FIRE SIREN DURING WEATHER EMERGENCIES.
   (A)   Council hereby authorizes the use of the fire siren to warn
inhabitants of the village of impending danger from tornado and/or winds of
unusually high velocity.
   (B)   The ranking police officer on duty and the member of the Fire
Department in charge when an advanced warning or notice of impending danger
from tornado or high wind is received, shall, jointly and individually, have
the duty and obligation to promptly sound the fire siren one prolonged blast of
not less than three minutes in duration and, at a subsequent time, to sound the
all-clear which shall be one continuous blast of one minute in duration.
(`94 Code, § 147.04)  (Ord. 15-74, passed 5-7-74; Am. Ord. 16-98, passed 7-28-
98)
§ 32.024  ESTABLISHMENT OF FIRE LINES.
   The Fire Chief or the Assistant Fire Chief may prescribe limits in the
vicinity of any fire, within which no person, except those who reside therein,
firefighters, police officers and those admitted by any officer of the Fire
Department, shall be permitted to come.
(`94 Code, § 147.05)
§ 32.025  CHARGES FOR SERVICES.
   (A)   Ambulance services.  The rates to be charged for services rendered by
the Ambulance Division to persons within the area of operation shall be as
follows:
      (1)   Basic Life Support (BLS) Service:               $568.00
      (2)   Advanced Life Support 1 (ALS1) Service:         $775.00
      (3)   Advanced Life Support 2 (ALS2) Service:         $1,084.00
      (4)   Trip mileage charge per loaded mile:            $14.20
(`94 Code, § 147.06)  (Ord. 13-88, passed 4-12-88; Am. Ord. 15-95, passed 5-15-
95; Am. Ord. 27-96, passed 12-10-96; Am. Ord. 31-2000, passed 10-24-00; Am.
Ord. 25-06, passed 8-8-06; Am. Ord. 26-2009, passed 12-28-09; Am. Ord. 26-2010,
passed 12-28-10; Am. Ord. 4-2013, passed 3-26-13; Am. Ord. 2-2014, passed 1-14-
14; Am. Ord. 31-2014, passed 12-23-14)
   (B)   Charges for transient vehicle fires.
      (1)   The rate to be charged by the village for services rendered by the
Fire Division to any nonresident owner of any vehicle for which a fire service
call is made with regard to such vehicle shall be $250 for each occurrence.
      (2)   The secretary of the Fire Division shall, within ten days after
rendition of the services set forth in division (B)(1) above, forward a
statement setting for the charges for such services, to the owner of the
vehicle which was the object of such services. Funds derived from such services
rendered shall be paid into the Operation and Maintenance Fund of the Fire
Division.
(`94 Code, § 147.07)  (Ord. 16-87, passed 12-8-87)

PLANNING COMMISSION
§ 32.085  ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERS.
   Pursuant to R.C. § 713.01, a Municipal Planning Commission is hereby
established. The Commission shall consist of five members as follows: the
Mayor, one member of Council to be elected thereby for the remainder of his or
her term as such member of Council, and three residents of the village. Such
resident members shall be appointed by the Mayor for terms of six years each.
The term of one of the resident members of the first Commission shall be for
four years and the term of one of such members shall be for two years. All
members shall serve without compensation.
(`94 Code, § 1105.01)  (Ord. 10-60, passed 2-23-60)
§ 32.086  FUNCTIONS.
   The Planning Commission shall function under the terms of R.C. § 713.01 and
other laws pertaining to its operation.
(`94 Code, § 1105.02)

CHAPTER 33:  MAYOR’S COURT
Section
   
33.01   Credit for fines
   
33.02   Release of prisoners
   
33.03   Records
   
33.04   Clerk of the Mayor’s Court
   
33.05   Mayor’s Court Improvements Fund
§ 33.01  CREDIT FOR FINES.
   Persons convicted of violating any of the provisions of this Code, or of any
other ordinance of the village, as the result of a hearing in the Mayor's
Court, may receive credit upon any fine in accordance with the provisions of
R.C. § 2947.14.
(`94 Code, § 171.01)  (Ord. 7-85, passed 9-10-85)
§ 33.02  RELEASE OF PRISONERS.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to discharge from imprisonment any person who
has been confined for nonpayment of a fine under this Code when he or she is
convinced that such fine cannot be collected by imprisonment or when he or she
is satisfied that the health of such person is in actual danger from such
imprisonment.
(`94 Code, § 171.02)
§ 33.03  RECORDS.
   The Mayor shall be provided by Council with a good, substantial docket, in
which he or she shall enter, by themselves, all proceedings on any complaint
for a violation of any of the provisions of this Code, or of any other
ordinance of the village, in the order and manner in which docket entries are
required by law to be made, and the time in which the prosecutions from which
the items of entry are made shall take place, and he or she shall carefully
preserve and file all papers relating to such proceedings. Upon the expiration
of his or her term of office, he or she shall deposit with his or her successor
in office his or her official docket, as well as those or his or her
predecessors, which may be in his or her custody, together with all files and
papers, laws and statutes pertaining to his or her office, to be kept as public
records and property, and in case of his or her death, resignation or removal
from office, the Mayor or his or her legal representatives shall deposit such
dockets, papers, laws and statutes with the Village Fiscal Officer for
safekeeping until a successor is chosen and qualified, at which time they shall
be delivered over to such successor on request.
(`94 Code, § 171.03)
§ 33.04  CLERK OF THE MAYOR’S COURT.
   The Mayor shall appoint a Clerk with the consent of Council who shall work
under the direct supervision of the Mayor and shall serve at the pleasure of
the Mayor and Council.  The duties of the Clerk shall be to attend the hearing
of the Mayor’s Court, to administer and schedule the Court docket, to collect
fines and Court costs, to submit records, reports and payments as required by
law, and to communicate and correspond with persons appearing in the Mayor’s
Court.
(Res. 2-2007, passed 3-13-07; Am. Res. 3-2007, passed 3-13-07)
§ 33.05  MAYOR’S COURT IMPROVEMENTS FUND. 
   (A)   The Council hereby authorized the establishment of a Mayor’s Court
Improvements Fund for designated monies collected by the Mayor’s Court and
payable to the village.  The Village Fiscal Officer is directed to submit the
establishment of this Fund for approval to the State Auditor pursuant to R.C.
5705.12.
   (B)   The monies collected by the Mayor’s Court and paid to the village from
a $10 fee assessed by the Court to provide for the capital needs, including
maintenance of capital improvements, of the Court shall be paid into the
Mayor’s Court Improvements Fund and that the monies deposited shall be used to
provide for the capital needs, including maintenance of capital improvements
and education of personnel of the Court.
   (C)   All revenues received pursuant to this division shall be deposited,
maintained and disbursed in the manner provided by this division.
   (D)   Any investment of monies deposited into the Mayor’s Court Improvements
Fund shall be made in accordance with the Village Investment Policy.
(Ord. 8-2007, passed 2-27-07; Am. Ord. 11-2007, passed 3-13-07)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 34.01  APPROVAL OF COUNCIL REQUIRED FOR EMPLOYMENT ACTIONS.
   No person shall be hired by the village, and no employee of the village
shall be promoted or receive a change in compensation without such hiring,
promotion or change in compensation being first approved by Council, except as
this Council may otherwise provide by ordinance or as may be otherwise provided
by law.
(Ord. 27-95, passed 12-12-95)
§ 34.02  BONDS.
   (A)   The following officers and employees of the village are hereby
required to post fidelity bonds for the faithful performance and execution of
their duties as follows:
      (1)   The Mayor, $5,000;
      (2)   The Administrator, $5,000;
      (3)   The Director of Taxation, $25,000; and
      (4)   The Police Dispatcher-Court Bailiff and Clerk, $5,000.
   (B)   All other officers and employees of the village shall be covered by a
blanket bond in the amount of $2,500 each.
   (C)   The premiums for all of the bonds required by divisions (A) and (B)
hereof shall be paid by the village from such funds as Council, from time to
time, determines.
(`94 Code, § 159.01)  (Am. Ord. 3-2003, passed 1-14-03)
§ 34.03  WORKWEEK; OVERTIME.
   (A)   (1)   The standard work week for village employees shall be 40 hours
per calendar week, unless otherwise provided. No overtime shall be worked
except with the prior approval of the Administrator or, in his or her absence,
the Mayor. An employee shall be compensated for all overtime worked by being
granted compensatory time off, on a one and one-half hour to one-hour basis.
However, when, in the opinion of the Administrator, it is more expedient and
necessary for the efficient operation of the village that overtime be paid in
cash, such overtime shall be paid at the rate of one and one-half times the
rate normally paid to the employees for his or her particular employment
classification. The Administrator shall report to the Finance Committee of
Council, on a monthly basis, the amount of overtime paid in cash. The
provisions hereof shall not apply to snow and ice removal.
      (2)   Overtime shall be based on actual hours worked in each 40 hours
workweek.
   (B)   The standard work week for all employees of the Village Police
Department shall be 40 hours per calendar week and each employee shall be paid
overtime in accordance with Section 3.02 of the Village Personnel and Procedure
Manual.
   (C)   No part-time village employee shall be permitted to regularly work 25
or more hours per week unless Council allocates funds to provide for the cost
of coverage of health insurance for the particular part-time employee.
(`94 Code, §159.02)  (Ord. 8-81, passed 2-26-81; Am. Ord. 17-2000, passed 7-11-
00; Am. Ord. 26-2003, passed 11-11-03; Am. Res. 1-2008, passed 1-8-08; Am. Ord.
18-2017, passed 9-12-17; Am. Ord. 14-2018, passed 7-24-18)
§ 34.04  HOSPITALIZATION AND LIFE INSURANCE.
   (A)   (1)   Hospitalization.  All full-time village employees are entitled
to group hospitalization medical insurance coverage for themselves and for
their dependents and dental and optical coverages to the extent permitted under
the plan(s). The premiums for such coverage shall be paid by the village from
the respective funds of the department in which the insured employee is
employed, except that the persons entitled to this benefit who are employed
with the village on or after March 1, 1993, the village shall pay a percentage
of the premium therefor as determined by Council. The employees’ contributions
shall be deducted from their pay checks from the village in a regular and
proportionate manner.
      (2)   Health insurance. 
         (a)   Part-time employees working 25 to 39 hours per week shall be
offered the opportunity to participate in the village Group Health Insurance
coverage, provided that employee pays 90% of the monthly premium.
         (b)   Part-time employees not desiring to receive the above offer of
coverage shall sign a waiver for the purpose of declining coverage.
(`94 Code, § 159.03)  (Ord. 8-93, passed 2-9-93; Am. Ord. 8-2012, passed 4-10-
12)
   (B)   Life Insurance.  All full-time village employees are entitled to group
life insurance coverage under such plan as is entered into by the village. The
premiums for such coverage shall be paid by the village from the respective
funds of the department in which the insured employee is employed.
(`94 Code, § 159.04)  (Ord. 8-81, passed 2-26-81; Am. Res. 3-2008, passed 2-26-
08)
§ 34.05  PAY PERIODS; WITHHOLDING OF PAY.
   The pay periods for all village employees shall be on alternating Fridays at
3:00 p.m. beginning January 1, 1979. One week of pay shall be withheld by the
Village Fiscal Officer from all persons in village employment on and after the
effective date of this section (Ordinance 8-81, passed February 26, 1981). The
one week of pay so withheld shall be paid to an employee upon termination of
his or her employment with the village.
(`94 Code, § 159.06)  (Ord. 8-81, passed 2-26-81)
§ 34.06  SICK LEAVE.
   An annual sick leave bonus shall be paid to any employee who completes 12
months of actual service as a regular full-time village employee in a calendar
year as follows:
   (A)   Sick leave shall be earned and accrued without limit.
   (B)   A village employee with ten or more years of village service who
retires under the Ohio Public Employees Retirement System or the Ohio Police
and Fire Pension Fund shall be paid one-fourth of their accrued sick leave, but
not exceeding 960 hours.
   (C)   After the accrual of 80 hours of sick leave, an employee may convert
up to 40 hours thereof to vacation. An employee must upon such conversion
accrue an additional 80 hours of sick leave before again being eligible for
another 40 vacation hour conversion.
(`94 Code, §159.07)  (Am. Ord. 24-2000, passed 9-12-00; Am. Ord. 6-2016, passed
5-10-16; Am. Ord. 19-2017, passed 9-12-17; Am. Ord. 23-2017, passed 11-14-17;
Am. Ord. 2-2019, passed 1-22-19; Am. Ord. 18-2021, passed 7-27-21)
§ 34.07  PAID HOLIDAYS.
   (A)   All full-time employees of the village shall receive 12 paid holidays
per year, as follows: New Year’s Day, Martin Luther King Day, President’s Day,
Good Friday, Memorial Day, Juneteenth (June 19th), Independence Day, Labor Day,
Veteran’s Day, Thanksgiving Day, the Friday following Thanksgiving Day,
Christmas Day, one floating holiday selected by the employee and one additional
day, per calendar year, to be selected by the Mayor. Unless otherwise
indicated, such holidays shall be celebrated on the same date that the holiday
is celebrated by federal employees. The floating holiday shall be exercised at
the option of the employee and the additional day shall be taken on the date
determined by the Mayor, which determination shall be made in the first month
of each year.
   (B)   To be eligible for paid holidays, an employee must work either the day
before or the day after the scheduled holiday.  Vacation hours shall be
considered as time worked.  Sick hours shall not be considered as time worked.
(`94 Code, §159.08)  (Ord. 9-94, passed 5-10-94; Am. Ord. 9-2000, passed 4-1-
00; Am. Ord. 2-2009, passed 1-13-09; Am. Ord. 17-2017, passed 9-12-17; Am. Ord.
18-2021, passed 7-27-21)
§ 34.08  VACATION; LEAVES OF ABSENCE.
   (A)   All full-time employees of the village shall receive paid vacation in
accordance with the following schedule:
      (1)   Computation of leave: Full-time employees working a scheduled 40
hours or more per week shall earn and be credited with annual vacation leave
according to their number of years of continuous service to the village of:
            Length of Service         Vacation Credits
         After completion of probation      40 hours
         After 1 year of service completed      40 hours
         After 3 years of service completed   120 hours
         After 7 years of service completed   160 hours
         After 15 years of service completed   200 hours
   (B)   An employee who becomes re-employed by the village subsequent to a
prior termination shall, for purposes of accumulated sick leave and annual
leave, commence the re-employment as a new employee and shall not be given
tenure or longevity status for the prior periods he or she was employed by the
village.
   (C)   The head of each department or the responsible board shall prepare a
vacation schedule in January of each year showing the times when village
employees, within their respective departments, will take their paid vacations.
This schedule must be approved by the Administrator for utility and service
department employees and by the Mayor for Police and Fire Department employees,
after consulting with Council before the schedule becomes final. An employee
may be allowed to reschedule his or her vacation by filing a written request
with the Administrator if he or she is employed in a utility or service
department, or the Mayor if employed in the Police or Fire Department, at least
two weeks prior to the scheduled vacation, or by applying to the Mayor for
emergency vacation time. The Mayor shall consult with Council and the
Administrator concerning utility and service department employees and the Chief
of Police concerning Police and Fire Department employees before granting or
denying any request to alter the scheduled vacation time or to grant leave for
emergency purposes.
   (D)   Every employee shall take his or her annual vacation in the form of
cash or time off within one year after becoming entitled to the same, except
employees may elect to carry over up to one week of vacation time at any one
time. An employee may elect each year to cash in vacation up to 40 hours
without Council's approval. Any employee's request exceeding 40 hours of
vacation cash conversion shall require Council's approval. Any employee who has
been authorized to receive part or all of his or her annual vacation time in
cash and continues to work during such period shall receive his or her regular
daily pay and an additional day of pay representing the vacation day accrued.
   (E)   Any village employee may be granted an emergency leave of absence,
without pay, by applying to the Administrator who is authorized to grant such
leave of absence in emergency situations. The Chief of Police must first
consent to the leave of absence of any employee of the Police Department. The
Administrator shall forthwith file a written report with the Mayor, setting
forth the name of the employee and the length of time off and, in essence, the
reason for granting such leave of absence.
(`94 Code, §159.09)  (Ord. 8-81, passed 2-26-81; Am. Ord. 6-86, passed 7-8-86;
Am. Ord. 10-2000, passed 4-24-00; Am. Ord. 18-2021, passed 7-27-21)
§ 34.09  USE OF THE TIME CLOCK.
   (A)   All employees of the utility and service departments and the Police
Department of the village are required to utilize the time clock facility daily
when reporting to and from work, except in circumstances where the use of the
time clock would be grossly inconvenient and impractical. Deviation from the
use of the time clock for any employee or group of employees shall only be
granted by a resolution duly enacted by Council. Failure to utilize the time
clock shall be grounds for dismissal of any employee from village employment as
shall falsification or the punching of a time card of another employee. This
requirement applies to hourly and salaried employees.
   (B)   Employees granted a deviation from using a time clock will record time
worked, vacations, holidays, sick leave and other leaves and absences on a time
card or time slip. Such time card or time slip shall be approved by the
department head, the Village Administrator or the Village Fiscal Officer prior
to payment of wages or salary covered on the time card or time slip. The
following employees are hereby granted a deviation from using a time clock:
      (1)   The Village Administrator;
      (2)   The Utility Clerk;
      (3)   The Meter Reader;
      (4)   The Cemetery Sexton;
      (5)   The Assistant Cemetery Sexton;
      (6)   The Park Custodian; and
      (7)   The Village Fiscal Officer.
(`94 Code, § 159.10)  (Ord. 8-81, passed 2-26-81; Am. Res. 10-82, passed 12-14-
82; Am. Ord. 3-2003, passed 1-14-03)
§ 34.10  OVERTIME FOR SALARIED EMPLOYEES; SPECIAL ASSIGNMENTS FOR POLICE.
   (A)   Except as otherwise herein provided, salaried employees shall not be
compensated for overtime work, except in cases of extraordinary emergency, but
in no event unless the number of hours worked per week exceeds 50, and even
then, only with the prior approval of the Mayor. Any compensation for overtime
work, as herein provided, must be approved by Council. If overtime is worked by
a salaried employee under circumstances authorized by this section, it shall be
paid at one and one-half times the regular hourly rate for the position or
classification held by the employee. A claim for overtime shall be submitted to
Council at the next regular meeting of Council following the time overtime is
incurred. The applicant for overtime compensation shall itemize the hours
worked and justify the need for such overtime compensation.
   (B)   An hourly rate as established from time to time by Council shall apply
to all overtime work for the purposes of snow and ice removal.
   (C)   (1)   Officers of the Police Department may be hired by various
organizations of the community with approval of the Chief of Police and the
Mayor to work special assignments, such as crowd control.
      (2)   The special assignments shall not interfere with performance of
employment schedules of the village.
      (3)   Officers working special assignments shall always comply with
village department rules and regulations.
      (4)   Officers working special assignments shall be directly hired by and
paid by such community organizations desiring their services.
(`94 Code, § 159.11)  (Ord. 8-81, passed 2-26-81; Am. Ord. 22-95, passed 10-17-
95; Am. Ord. 35-2014, passed 12-23-14)
§ 34.11  RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT.
   All full-time employees must reside within 12 miles of the corporate limits
of the village or must, within 30 days after completing a satisfactory
probation period as an employee, establish residency within 12 miles of the
corporate limits of the village.  This section shall not apply to or affect any
village employee who, as of August 8, 1976, did not meet the residency
requirement, until such time when such nonresident employee relinquishes such
nonqualifying residence, at which time this section shall become effective and
viable as to such employee.
(`94 Code, § 159.12)  (Ord. 8-81, passed 2-26-81; Am. Ord. 30-2000, passed 10-
24-00)
§ 34.12  LONGEVITY COMPENSATION.
   All full-time village employees shall receive, in addition to any other
compensation provided for in the general compensation ordinance, an additional
$100 annual longevity payment for each continuous year of village service until
their date of separation or retirement.
(`94 Code, §159.13)  (Ord. 9-86, passed 12-9-86; Am. Ord. 18-2021, passed 7-27-
21)
§ 34.13  FLEXIBLE BENEFITS PLAN.
   The Village Council hereby adopts a cafeteria plan within the context of
Section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code for the benefit of eligible village
employees.
(Res. 9-2002, passed 2-14-02)
FAMILY AND MEDICAL LEAVE OF ABSENCE
§ 34.20  FAMILY AND MEDICAL LEAVE OF ABSENCE POLICY.
   Family and Medical Leave of Absence is provided in keeping with the Family
and Medical Leave Act of 1993. This leave shall apply to all family and medical
leaves of absence except to the extent that such leaves are covered under other
paid employment benefit policies for any part of the 12 weeks of leave to which
the employee may be entitled under this provision. In other words, if an
employee is entitled to paid leave under other provisions of the Personnel
Policy Manual, the employee must take the paid leave first and if the paid
leave is less than 12 weeks, the additional weeks of leave necessary to attain
the 12 work weeks of leave required by the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993
shall be taken without compensation.
(Ord. 4-2008, passed 1-22-08)
§ 34.21  DEFINITIONS.
   For purposes of administering Family and Medical Leave, the following
definitions shall be and are adopted:
   HEALTH CARE PROVIDER. The term means:
      (1)   A doctor of medicine or osteopathy who is authorized to practice
medicine or surgery (as appropriate) by the state in which the doctor
practices; or
      (2)   Any other person determined by Federal mandate to be capable of
providing health care services.
   PARENT.  The biological parent of an employee or an individual who stood in
loco parentis to an employee when the employee was a son or daughter.
   REDUCED LEAVE SCHEDULE.  A leave schedule that reduces the usual number of
hours per work week, or hours per work day, of an employee.
   SERIOUS HEALTH CONDITION.  An illness, injury, impairment, or physical or
mental condition that involves:
      (1)   Inpatient care in a hospital, hospice, or residential medical care
facility; or
      (2)   Continuing treatment by a health care provider.
   SON or DAUGHTER. A biological, adopted, or foster child, a stepchild, a
legal ward, or a child of a person standing in loco parentis, who is:
      (1)   Under 18 years of age; or
      (2)   Eighteen years of age or older and incapable of self care because
of a mental or physical disability.
   SPOUSE. A husband or wife, as the case may be.
   TWELVE-MONTH PERIOD . The 12-month period during which the 12 weeks of leave
may be taken shall be a rolling 12-month period measured backward from the time
an employee uses any twelve week leave. Each time an employee takes FMLA leave,
the remaining leave entitlement would be any balance of the 12 weeks that has
not been used during the immediately preceding 12 months.
(Ord. 4-2008, passed 1-22-08)
§ 34.22  ELIGIBILITY FOR LEAVE.
   (A)   To be eligible for leave, an employee must have been employed for at
least 12 months in total, and must have worked at least 1250 hours during the
12-month period preceding the commencement of the leave. The leave may be
granted for one or more of the following for a total of 12 work weeks of leave
during any 12-month period:
      (1)   Because of the birth of a son or daughter of the employee and in
order to care for such son or daughter.
      (2)   Because of the placement of a son or daughter with the employee for
adoption or foster care.
      (3)   In order to care for the spouse, or a son, daughter, or parent of
the employee, if such spouse, son, daughter or parent has a serious health
condition.
      (4)   Because of a serious health condition that makes the employee
unable to perform the functions of the position of such employee.
   (B)   The entitlement to leave under division (A)(1) or (2) shall expire at
the end of the 12-month period beginning on the date of such birth or
placement. Leave under division (A)(1) or (2) shall not be taken intermittently
or on a reduced leave schedule.
   (C)   The entitlement to leave under division (A)(3) or (4) may be as
follows:
      (1)   The leave must be medically necessary. If leave is so requested,
then the Village may require the employee to provide medical certification to
support a claim for leave for the employee's own serious health condition or to
care for a seriously ill child, spouse or parent. For the employee's own
medical leave, the certification must include a statement that the employee is
unable to perform the functions of his or her position. For leave to care for a
seriously ill child, spouse or parent, the certification must include an
estimate of the amount of time the employee is needed to provide care. In its
discretion, the village may require a second medical opinion and periodic
recertification at its own expense. If the first and second opinions differ,
the village may require the binding opinion of a third health care provider,
approved jointly by the village and the employee.
      (2)   If medically necessary for a serious health condition of the
employee or his or her spouse, child or parent, leave may be taken on an
intermittent or reduced leave schedule. If leave is requested on this basis,
however, the village may require the employee to transfer temporarily to an
alternative position which better accommodates recurring periods of absence or
a part-time schedule, provided that the position has equivalent pay and
benefits.
      (3)   Spouses who are both employed by the village are entitled to a
total of 12 weeks of leave (rather than 12-weeks each) for the birth or
adoption of a child or for the care of a sick parent.
(Ord. 4-2008, passed 1-22-08)
§ 34.23  NOTIFICATION AND REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.
   When the need for leave is foreseeable, such as the birth or adoption of a
child, or planned medical treatment, the employee must provide reasonable prior
notice, and make efforts to schedule leave so as not to disrupt the village's
operations. In cases of illness, the employee will be required to report
periodically on his or her leave status and intention to return to work.
(Ord. 4-2008, passed 1-22-08)
§ 34.24  STATUS OF EMPLOYEE BENEFITS DURING LEAVE OF ABSENCE.
   (A)   Any employee who is granted an approved leave of absence under this
policy is advised to provide for the retention of his or her group insurance
coverage by arranging to pay the premium contributions during the period of
unpaid absence.
   (B)   In the event that an employee elects not to return to work upon
completion of an approved unpaid leave of absence, the village may recover from
the employee the cost of any payments made to maintain the employee's coverage,
unless the failure to return to work was for reason beyond the employee's
control. Benefit entitlements based upon length of service will be calculated
as of the last paid work day prior to the start of the unpaid leave of absence.
(Ord. 4-2008, passed 1-22-08)
§ 34.25  COMPLETION OF LEAVE FORM.
   (A)   A request for Family and Medical Leave of Absence Form must be
originated in duplicate by the employee. This form should be completed in
detail, signed by the employee, and submitted to the immediate supervisor for
proper approval. If possible, the form should be submitted 30 days in advance
of the effective date of the leave.
   (B)   All requests for family and medical leaves of absence due to illness
will include the following information attached to a completed Request for
Family and Medical Leave of Absence:
      (1)   Sufficient medical certification stating:
         (a)   The date on which the serious health condition commenced;
         (b)   The probable duration of the condition; and
         (c)   The appropriate medical facts within the knowledge of the health
care provider regarding the condition. In addition, for purposes of leave to
care for a child, spouse, or parent, the certificate should give an estimate of
the amount of time that the employee is needed to provide such care.
      (2)   For purposes of leave for an employee's illness, the certificate
must state that the employee is unable to perform the functions of his or her
position. In the case of certification for intermittent leave or leave on a
reduced leave schedule for planned medical treatment, the dates on which such
treatment is expected to be given and the duration of such treatment must be
stated.
(Ord. 4-2008, passed 1-22-08)
CHAPTER 35:  INCOME TAX EFFECTIVE UNTIL DECEMBER 31, 2015
