GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 153.001  INTERPRETATION, APPLICATION AND PURPOSES.
   (A)   In their interpretation and application, the provisions of these
Subdivision Regulations (this chapter) shall be held to be the minimum
requirements adopted for the protection of the public health, safety and
welfare. Among other purposes, such provisions are intended to provide
permanently for a wholesome community environment, adequate municipal services
and safe streets to protect the public.
   (B)   These Subdivision Regulations shall not apply to any lot forming a
part of a subdivision created and recorded prior to the effective date of these
subdivision regulations.
(`94 Code, § 1121.01)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.002  CONFLICTS OF LAW.
   These Subdivision Regulations are not intended to repeal, abrogate, annul or
in any way impair or interfere with existing provisions of other laws or
ordinances, except those specifically repealed by these Subdivision
Regulations, or with private restrictions placed upon property by deed,
covenant or other private agreement, or with restrictive covenants running with
the land to which the village is a party. Where any of the provisions of these
Subdivision Regulations imposes a greater restriction on land than is imposed
or required by an existing provision of a law, ordinance, contract or deed, the
provision of these Subdivision Regulations shall prevail.
(`94 Code, § 1121.02)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.003  AREA OF JURISDICTION.
   These Subdivision Regulations shall apply within the corporate limits of the
village and in the unincorporated area lying within three miles of such
corporate limits, subject to limitations specified in R.C. § 711.09.
(`94 Code, § 1121.03)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.004  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ADMINISTRATOR.  The Administrator of the village.
   BLOCK.  A parcel of land bounded on all sides by a street or streets.
   COUNCIL.  The Council of the village.
   COUNTY.  Huron County and Richland County, Ohio.
   COUNTY ENGINEER.  The Engineers of Huron and Richland Counties.
   CUL-DE-SAC.  See STREET.
   DEVELOPER.  An individual, group of individuals, organization or other legal
entity undertaking or contracting for construction of improvements on
subdivided land.
   EASEMENT.  A grant, by a property owner to an individual, group of
individuals, organization or other legal entity, for the use of a certain
parcel of land for a specified purpose.
   ENGINEER.  The Engineer of the village.
   IMPROVEMENTS.  Streets, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, sanitary and storm
sewers, water services and such other facilities as may be required for the
subdivision and development of land under these Subdivision Regulations.
   LOT.  A piece, parcel or tract of land separated from other parcels by lot
lines and having frontage on a public street. In addition:
      (1)   CORNER LOT.  A lot at the juncture of, and fronting upon, two or
more intersecting streets or upon two parts of the same street, such streets or
parts of the same forming an interior angle of less than 135 degrees. The point
of intersection of the street lot lines is the corner.
      (2)   INTERIOR LOT.  Any lot other than a corner lot.
      (3)   LOT AREA.  The computed land area contained within the lot lines,
usually expressed in square feet or in acres and fractions thereof.
      (4)   LOT DEPTH.  The mean horizontal distance between the front and rear
lot lines.
      (5)   LOT LINES.  the property lines bounding a lot.
         (a)   FRONT LOT LINE.  The line separating a lot from the street on
which it abuts.
         (b)   REAR LOT LINE.  The lot line opposite to, and most distant from,
the front lot line.
         (c)   SIDE LOT LINE.  Any lot line other than a front or rear lot
line. A side lot line separating a lot from a street is a side street lot line.
A side lot line separating a lot from another lot is an interior side lot line.
      (6)   LOT SPLIT.  The division of a single parcel of land into at least
two, but not more than five, lots, either at the same time or over a period of
time.
      (7)   LOT WIDTH.  The mean horizontal distance between the side lot lines
measured at right angles to the depth of the lot.
   MAP.  A scaled drawing or reproduction thereof of a parcel of land or a
subdivision of land.
      (1)   FINAL PLAT MAP.  A final proposal for the subdivision of land,
presented in map form to the Planning Commission for approval, and which, if
approved, shall become the official recorded plat of that subdivision.
      (2)   PRELIMINARY PLAT MAP.  A tentative proposal for the subdivision of
land under these Subdivision Regulations, submitted in map form to the Planning
Commission for its consideration in accordance with the procedures specified in
these Subdivision Regulations.
      (3)   VICINITY MAP.  A small map identifying the location of a proposed
subdivision of land with reference to known points in the area around it.
   OWNER.  An individual, group of individuals, organization or any other legal
entity having sufficient proprietary interest in land sought to be subdivided
to commence and maintain proceedings to subdivide the same under these
Subdivision Regulations.
   PLANNING COMMISSION.  The Planning Commission of the village.
   REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION.  The Planning Commissions of Huron and
Richland Counties.
   RIGHT-OF-WAY.  The area between property lines utilized or reserved for use
as a public street, alley or pedestrian way.
   STREET.  A public right-of-way for vehicular traffic, including, but not
limited to, a highway, thoroughfare, parkway, road, avenue, boulevard, lane,
drive, court or circle.
      (1)   ALLEY.  A vehicular right-of-way providing a secondary means of
access to the rear or side of abutting properties.
      (2)   CUL-DE-SAC.  A minor street having one end open to vehicular
traffic and the other end permanently terminated by a vehicular turn-around.
      (3)   DEAD-END STREET.  A street having one end open to vehicular traffic
and the other end temporarily terminated by a vehicular turn-around.
      (4)   MAJOR STREET and ARTERIAL STREET.  A street of considerable
continuity utilized for the movement of traffic between large and/or widely
separated areas.
      (5)   MINOR STREET and LOCAL STREET.  A street utilized primarily for
access to abutting properties.
      (6)   SECONDARY STREET and COLLECTOR STREET. A street of intermediate
continuity utilized for the movement of traffic between arterial streets and
local streets.
   SUBDIVIDER.  An individual, group of individuals, organization or any other
legal entity commencing proceedings to subdivide land under these Subdivision
Regulations.
   SUBDIVISION.  The division of a parcel of land into two or more parcels for
the purposes, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or the
improvement of one or more parcels of land, involving the division or
allocation of land for the opening, widening or extension of a street, the
creation of open spaces for common use by abutting properties or the granting
of easements for extension and maintenance of public utilities.
   UTILITIES EASEMENT.  An easement granted for the installation and/or
maintenance of public utilities.
   VERTICAL VISIBILITY.  The minimum unobstructed distance between the top of
an object four inches high placed on the centerline of a street and another
point on the centerline of the same street located 4.5 feet above the surface
thereof.
   VILLAGE.  The Village of Plymouth, Ohio.
(`94 Code, § 1121.04)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
PRELIMINARY PLATS
§ 153.015  NUMBER OF COPIES REQUIRED; SUBMISSION OF COPIES.
   (A)   Number of copies required.  The following number of copies of
preliminary plat components are required:
 
                     In the Village In the Three-Mile
                                    Area of Jurisdiction
Applications         1              1
Preliminary maps     4              6
Protective covenants 1              1
Vicinity maps        1              2
 
(`94 Code, § 1125.01)
   (B)   Submission of copies.  The subdivider shall submit the required number
of copies of the preliminary plat to the Village Administrator not later than
15 working days prior to the next meeting of the Planning Commission.  (`94
Code, § 1125.02)
(Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.016  PUBLIC HEARINGS; NOTICE.
   A public hearing on the proposed plat shall be held by the Planning
Commission and shall be scheduled to occur at the same time and place as the
meeting at which the proposed plat is to be considered by the Commission.
Notice of the hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation
in the village not later than ten days prior to the meeting. Owners of lands
immediately adjacent to the lands shown on the proposed plat shall be given
notice by certified mail at least five days prior to such meeting.
(`94 Code, § 1125.03)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.017  EVALUATION REPORTS.
   The Village Administrator shall prepare a report evaluating the conformity
of the proposed plat with design standards and regulations and make such
recommendations for alteration as he or she deems necessary.
(`94 Code, § 1125.04)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.018  APPROVAL OR DENIAL.
   At its meetings, the Planning Commission shall hear the report of the
Village Administrator upon the proposed plat and shall hold a public hearing
thereon. Following the hearing, the Commission may take action as follows:
   (A)   Approval. The Commission may approve the preliminary plat and
authorize the subdivider to proceed with the preparation of the final plat.
   (B)   Approval in Principle. The Commission may give approval in principle
when, in the judgment of the Commission, it is clear that defects in the plat
can be corrected and that the subdivider is clearly willing to make such
corrections as are necessary and required by the Commission. Such approval in
principle shall not bind the Commission to subsequent favorable action on the
preliminary plat, but shall serve as an indication of specific problems to be
solved by the subdivider before favorable action can be taken.
   (C)   Tabling. The Commission may table the proposed plat for further
consideration, subject to the time limitation specified in §
153.019.
   (D)   Denial. The Commission may deny the proposed plat for failure to
comply with the regulations and standards specified in §
153.020.
(`94 Code, § 1125.05)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.019  TIME LIMITATIONS.
   (A)   A preliminary plat not acted upon by the Planning Commission within 60
calendar days after the date of submission shall be considered approved as
submitted.
   (B)   The approval of the preliminary plat shall be valid for not more than
two years.
(`94 Code, § 1125.06)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.020  PRELIMINARY PLAT MAP CONTENTS.
   The preliminary plat map shall be drawn to a scale of not more than 400 feet
to the inch and shall contain the following data and information:
   (A)   The name of the subdivision and its location by section, town, range
and township, the names and addresses of the owner, subdivider and engineer and
the scale and north point of the map;
   (B)   The boundaries of the proposed plat, with the names of adjacent
property owners or subdivisions;
   (C)   The locations, right-of-way widths and names of all existing or
platted streets, railroads, utilities or right-of-way easements within 200 feet
of the proposed plat;
   (D)   Zoning districts, building setback lines, with dimensions, and
easements, with dimensions;
   (E)   Existing contours with intervals of not more than five feet where the
slope is greater than 10% and not more than two feet where the slope is less
than 10%. Elevations shall be shown relative to sea level data;
   (F)   The locations, rights-of-way and names of all proposed streets, the
locations and dimensions of all sidewalks and easements and the layout,
dimensions and numbers of all proposed lots;
   (G)   The land reserved or dedicated for public use or reserved for the
common use of property owners;
   (H)   The locations of existing sewers, water mains, culverts and other
utilities, above or below ground, in the tract and within 200 feet thereof,
together with pipe sizes and grades; and
   (I)   The locations of proposed sewers, drainage courses and water mains in
the tract and within 200 feet thereof.
(`94 Code, § 1125.07)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
FINAL PLATS
§ 153.035  NUMBER OF COPIES REQUIRED; SUBMISSION OF COPIES.
   (A)   Number of copies required.  The following number of copies of final
plat components are required:
 
                      In the Village In the Three-Mile
                                     Area of Jurisdiction
Applications          1              1
Construction drawings 3              6
Cost estimates        2              3
Final maps            3              6
 
(`94 Code, § 1129.01)
   (B)   Submission of copies.  The subdivider shall submit the required number
of copies of the final plat to the Village Administrator not later than seven
working days prior to the next meeting of the Planning Commission. 
(`94 Code, § 1129.02)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.036  REVIEW AND APPROVAL.
   (A)   At its meeting, the Planning Commission shall review the final plat
for conformity with the preliminary plat and all other requirements of these
Subdivision Regulations. If the plat is found to meet such requirements, the
Commission shall approve the plat and recommend its approval by Council.
   (B)   Within 30 days after receipt of the final plat, Council shall approve
the plat. The subdivider shall accompany such submission with evidence that all
improvements have been completed to the satisfaction of the Village
Administrator or shall post a bond for 100% of the cost of such improvements
pending the completion thereof.
(`94 Code, § 1129.03)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.037  NOTIFICATION OF SUBDIVIDER; RECORDING.
   The Village Administrator shall notify the subdivider of the decisions of
the Planning Commission and Council, by mail, within five working days after
the date of such action. The subdivider is then required to record the plat
with the County Recorder within 90 days. If such recording is not made within
90 days, the approval shall become void and reapplication must be made.
(`94 Code, § 1129.04)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.038  FILE COPIES.
   After recording the plat in the manner prescribed in §
153.037, the subdivider shall file with the village a reproducible tracing on
cloth or an equally durable substitute of the final plat.
(`94 Code, § 1129.05)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.039  TIME LIMITATIONS.
   If the final plat is not approved within 30 days from the date of
submission, the provisions of R.C. § 711.09 shall apply.
(`94 Code, § 1129.06)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.040  FINAL PLAT MAP CONTENTS.
   The final plat map shall be drawn to a scale of not more than 100 feet to
the inch in India ink on tracing cloth or an equally durable substitute and
shall contain the following data and information:
   (A)   The name of the subdivision, its location by section, town, range,
township, county and state, its acreage and the scale and north point of the
map;
   (B)   The names of the owner or owners of record, the subdivider and the
registered surveyor who prepared the plat and the location and ownership of
adjoining property;
   (C)   Certification by a surveyor or engineer registered in the state that
the plan represents a survey made by him or her and that all monuments shown
thereon actually exist and that their locations, size and material are
correctly shown;
   (D)   A statement dedicating land offered for public use, or property to be
reserved for the common use of property owners, along with identification and
measurement thereof;
   (E)   Protective covenants and restrictions;
   (F)   A statement of approval by the Planning Commission and a statement of
acceptance by the Village Administrator and, if the plat is within the three-
mile area of jurisdiction, a statement of acceptance by the County
Commissioners of Huron County, Ohio, or the County Commissioners of Richland
County, Ohio.
   (G)   A statement of acknowledgment by the owner of his or her adoption of
the plat and dedication of streets and other public areas;
   (H)   A certificate of a notary public and evidence of title from an
attorney at law;
   (I)   If a zoning change is involved, certification by Council or the
appropriate Planning Commission that such change has been approved;
   (J)   The boundary lines of the area being subdivided with accurate
dimensions and bearings. The exterior boundary, when computed from field
measurements on the ground, shall close to an error of not more than one in
10,000 before balancing survey.
   (K)   Plat boundaries, which shall be tied to existing monuments, street
lines, section corners or other survey lines by bearings and distances and
which shall be accurately described or located on the plat;
   (L)   A known reference point and any corporation, section, township or
county line crossing or immediately adjacent thereto;
   (M)   The location of all proposed or existing monuments and bench marks
within the plat or immediately adjacent to the plat;
   (N)   All lot lines with the necessary distances and bearings, all linear
dimensions and angular measurements and a numbering system identifying each
lot;
   (O)   Building setback lines with dimensions;
   (P)   A plan and profile of all streets and storm and sanitary sewer lines;
   (Q)   A plan of all water lines; and
   (R)   The measurement and identification of areas reserved for schools,
parks or common use.
(`94 Code, § 1129.07)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.041  FINAL PLAT MAP PLATTING DETAIL.
   The platting detail on the final plat map shall be as follows:
   (A)   All bearings and angles shall be to the nearest second and all
distances to one hundredth of a foot.
   (B)   Street and other right-of-way lines, both within and adjacent to the
plat, and their names, bearings and widths (including widths along the line of
any obliquely intersecting street, lot or tract boundary line) shall be given.
   (C)   Street intersection corners shall have the radius, central angle, arc
length and tangent given.
   (D)   Curve data shall be given for each lot or parcel (radius, arc length,
central angle and chord).
(`94 Code, § 1129.08)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
DESIGN STANDARDS
§ 153.060  STREETS.
   (A)   Layout pattern. Street layout shall conform to the general pattern
shown on the Major Thoroughfare Plan and with these Subdivision Regulations and
shall be designed with due regard to topography, drainage and other physical
considerations.
   (B)   Continuity. The street pattern shall make provisions of the
continuance of streets into adjacent vacant property and for connection to
existing rights-of-way in adjacent developed property.
   (C)   Names.  The names of new streets shall not duplicate existing street
names except where coterminous or where the new right-of-way is in alignment
with an existing one. All new streets shall be named in accordance with the
following schedule:
General Direction of Street Name Ends With
North and south             Street
East and west               Avenue
Diagonal                    Road
Curving                     Drive
Cul-de-sac, north and south Place
Cul-de-sac, east and west   Court
Circular, or part thereof   Circle
Alley, east and west        Lane
Alley, north and south      Way
 
   (D)   Widths, grades, curve radii.  Streets shall be designed in accordance
with the following standards:
 
                      Minimum     Maximum   Maximum              Minimum
Type of     Right of  Pavement    Grade     Curve   Minimum      Vertical
Street      way (ft.) (back to    (percent) (deg.)  Radius (ft.) Visibility
                      back) (ft.)                                (ft.)
Arterial
(major)     80        24 plus 24  4         5       1,150        500
divided
Undivided   70        48          4         5       1,150        500
Collector   60        36          8         20      300          200
(secondary)
Local       50        28          10        --      ---          ---
(minor)
 
   (E)   Intersections.
      (1)   Streets shall intersect at right angles wherever possible and
practical.
      (2)   Curb lines at intersections shall be rounded to a minimum radius of
25 feet and property lines at intersections to a minimum radius of 15 feet.
      (3)   Street grade shall not exceed 3% within 100 feet of an
intersection, except that the maximum percentage herein set forth may be
exceeded due to topography, upon the recommendation of the Planning Commission
and approval of Council.
      (4)   The approach to an intersection shall be perpendicular to the
intersected street for a distance of not less than 100 feet from the centerline
of the intersected street.
      (5)   Jogs of less than 125 feet from centerline to centerline are not
permitted.
   (F)   Dead-ends and cul-de-sacs.
      (1)   Dead-end streets are not permitted unless they are provided with a
paved cul-de-sac having a right-of-way radius of not less than 50 feet and a
pavement radius of not less than 40 feet, except in the case of a cul-de-sac
having an island in the center thereof, in which case, the island may not
exceed a diameter of 44 feet. The right-of-way radius of a cul-de-sac having an
island must be not less than 60 feet and the pavement width must be not less
than 28 feet. The developer of a cul-de-sac having an island shall provide for
the perpetual development and maintenance thereof by the property owners
adjoining the cul-de-sac. In the event any such island is inadequately
maintained for a period of one year or becomes a traffic or safety hazard, the
village may, after 30 days written notice to the adjoining property owners
thereof, remove such island and assess the cost for such removal and the cost
of improvement of the cul-de-sac to the adjoining property owners. Dedication
of the cul-de-sac shall not be accepted without adequate assurance of
appropriate deed restrictions to ensure compliance with this section.
      (2)   The maximum length of a cul-de-sac shall be 600 feet measured from
the center of the turn-around to the centerline of the intersecting street.
      (3)   Where a street ends at a subdivision line to be extended in the
future, it shall be provided with a temporary turn-around until such extension
is completed.
   (G)   Half or partial streets. The dedication of half or partial streets is
not permitted, except when a half or partial street exists adjacent to the
tract to be subdivided, in which case the other portion of such half or partial
street shall be dedicated.
   (H)   Alleys.
      (1)   Alleys are not permitted in single and two-family districts, unless
necessitated by unusual circumstances.
      (2)   Alleys shall be provided in multifamily, business and industrial
districts, unless satisfactory alternate arrangements are made for access to
off-street parking, loading and service areas.
      (3)   The minimum width of an alley shall be 20 feet.
      (4)   Dead-end alleys are not permitted.
(`94 Code, § 1131.01)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70; Am. Ord. 16-96, passed 7-9-
96; Am. Ord. 17-96, passed 8-13-96) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.061  BLOCKS.
   The length, width and shape of a block shall be determined with due regard
to the need for access, areas of buildable sites and limitations of topography,
but in no case shall a block exceed 2,000 feet in length.
(`94 Code, § 1131.02)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.062  LOTS.
   (A)   Frontage.
      (1)   All lots shall abut by their full frontage on a public street.
      (2)   Double frontage lots, other than corner lots or lots backing on a
major street, are not permitted.
   (B)   Minimum Size. Except as modified by applicable zoning regulations, all
lots shall meet or exceed the following minimum sizes:
      (1)   Area.  Each lot served by both water and sanitary sewer facilities
shall have a minimum area of 7,500 square feet. If either water or sanitary
facilities, or both, are not available to the lot, the lot shall have such
minimum area as is determined by the health agency having jurisdiction in the
area.
      (2)   Width. Each interior lot shall have an average minimum width of 60
feet and a width of at least 40 feet at the building line. Each corner lot
shall have a minimum width of 65 feet as measured across the least width of
less than 20 feet at any point.
      (3)   Depth. Each lot shall have an average minimum depth of 125 feet.
   (C)   Shape.
      (1)   All lots shall be as nearly rectangular as practical. Irregular or
odd-shaped lots will be permitted only when unavoidable and then only when
sufficiently large to permit reasonable construction and occupancy of permitted
structures.
      (2)   The average depth of a lot shall be not greater than three times
its average width.
      (3)   Triangular lots are not permitted.
   (D)   Lines.
      (1)   Side lot lines shall be approximately perpendicular to the street
line or radial to a curved street line.
      (2)   Curved side or rear lot lines are not permitted.
   (E)   Setbacks.  Except as modified by applicable zoning regulations, the
minimum building set-back line on residential lots shall be 25 feet, measured
from the street right-of-way.
   (F)   Corner Lots. Corner lots shall be designed with due regard to setbacks
and side yard limitations to allow reasonable construction and occupancy of
permitted structures.
   (G)   Minimum Depth; Easements. Lots backing on a major street shall have a
minimum depth of 150 feet. A ten-foot easement shall be required at the rear
line of such lots and vehicular access shall not be permitted across such
easement.
(`94 Code, § 1131.03)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.063  EASEMENTS.
   (A)   Easements for utilities or other purposes shall be located along rear
lot lines, and where necessary, along side lot lines.
   (B)   Easements shall normally be ten feet in width, with five feet on each
side of the lot line. Greater widths may be required if necessitated by unusual
circumstances.
(`94 Code, § 1131.04)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
IMPROVEMENTS
§ 153.075  CONFORMITY OF IMPROVEMENTS WITH AGENCY SPECIFICATIONS; COMPLETION OF
IMPROVEMENTS OR BOND REQUIRED.
   All improvements required by these Subdivision Regulations shall be
constructed and completed under the supervision of, and to the specifications
required by, the agency or agencies having jurisdiction over them. Final
approval of any plat shall be withheld until all required improvements are
completed to the satisfaction of the agency or agencies involved, or until bond
has been posted in favor of the village in the amount of 100% of the estimated
cost of the improvements.
(`94 Code, § 1133.01)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.076  STREETS.
   (A)   New Streets. New streets shall be paved to the minimum width specified
in §
153.060(D), provided that in the case of an arterial major street, the
requirements may be modified in one of the following ways:
      (1)   The subdivider shall not be required to pave any such arterial
street to a width of more than 25 feet on each side of the centerline thereof,
or the equivalent in the case of a divided pavement.
      (2)   The subdivider may enter into a contract with the village to pay
into the village treasury an amount equal to the cost of pavement as required
by division (A)(1) hereof, which amount shall then be used by the village in
construction of such arterial street.
      (3)   If all lots are to back on such arterial street, the requirements
for paving shall not apply.
   (B)   Existing Streets. When land is being subdivided along an existing
street, the village may require that the pavement be widened. Such widening
need not exceed 18 feet on each side of the centerline.
   (C)   Grades and Curves. Grades and curves shall not exceed the requirements
specified in §
153.060.
   (D)   Materials and Specifications. Materials and specifications for the
design and construction of streets, pavements, curbs and gutters, as required
by this section, shall be in conformity with the current specifications on file
in the office of the Village Engineer.
(`94 Code, § 1133.02)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.077  SIDEWALKS.
   (A)   The installation of sidewalks is optional on a minor street. On a
major arterial street, sidewalks are mandatory on both sides of the street.
   (B)   Where installation is required, a sidewalk shall be 40 inches wide
with the line nearest the abutting property one foot from the abutting property
line.
   (C)   Materials and specifications for the design and construction of
sidewalks, as required by this section, shall be in conformity with current
specifications on file in the office of the Administrator.
(`94 Code, § 1133.03)  (Ord. 24-81, passed 8-13-81) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.078  WATER SUPPLY; FIRE HYDRANTS.
   (A)   A water supply serving all lots in a subdivision is hereby required.
   (B)   Where a public water supply is available, as determined by the
village, every lot in the subdivision shall be provided with a connection
thereto at the expense of the subdivider.
   (C)   Where a public water supply is not available, as determined by the
village, the subdivider shall construct wells or another private system,
subject to approval by the village or the county agency having jurisdiction.
   (D)   Fire hydrants shall be installed in all subdivisions at all street
intersections and other points at intervals of not more than 600 feet.
   (E)   Materials and specifications for the design and construction of water
supplies and fire hydrants, as required by this section, shall be in conformity
with the current specifications on file in the office of the Village Engineer.
(`94 Code, § 1133.04)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.079  SANITARY SEWERAGE SYSTEMS.
   (A)   A sanitary sewage disposal system serving all lots in a subdivision is
hereby required.
   (B)   Where a public sanitary sewerage system is available, as determined by
the village, every lot in the subdivision shall be provided with a connection
thereto at the expense of the subdivider.
   (C)   Where a public sanitary sewer is not available, as determined by the
village, the subdivider shall provide an acceptable disposal system, subject to
approval by the village or the county agency having jurisdiction.
   (D)   Materials and specifications for the design and construction of
sanitary sewage disposal facilities, as required by this section, shall be in
conformity with the current specifications on file in the office of the Village
Engineer.
(`94 Code, § 1133.05)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.080  STORM SEWERAGE SYSTEMS; GRADING OF LOTS.
   (A)   A system for disposal of storm drainage in all subdivisions is hereby
required.
   (B)   Where an existing public storm drainage facility is available, as
determined by the village, the storm drainage system of a subdivision shall be
connected thereto.
   (C)   Where connection to a public storm drainage system is not possible, as
determined by the village, the subdivider shall make such alternate provisions
for storm drainage disposal as are approved by the village or the county agency
having jurisdiction.
   (D)   Each lot in a subdivision shall be so graded as to permit the flow of
storm drainage from the entire lot to a public system for disposal.
   (E)   Materials and specifications for the design and construction of storm
drainage disposal facilities, as required by this section, shall be in
conformity with the current specifications on file in the office of the Village
Engineer.
(`94 Code, § 1133.06)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
§ 153.081  OTHER IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   Street name signs shall be provided at all street intersections and
shall be of a type approved by the Village Administrator. Such signs shall be
placed in conformity with the current specifications on file in the office of
the Village Engineer.
   (B)   Street lighting of a type approved by the Village Administrator shall
be provided in all subdivisions.
   (C)   Street tree planting plans may be submitted to the Administrator for
approval and, if approved, such trees shall be planted in accordance with the
provisions of applicable ordinances and regulations.
   (D)   Monuments consisting of steel pins one inch in diameter and not less
than 30 inches in length shall be placed at all angle points, points of curves
in streets and intermediate points, as required by the village, and at all lot
corners.
   (E)   Permanent monuments consisting of stone or concrete 36 inches in
length and six inches in diameter, with a reinforcing bar or pipe cast in the
center, shall be placed at all block corners and at the intersection of all
subdivision boundary lines.
   (F)   Public areas shall be required as specified by applicable ordinances
and regulations.
   (G)   The subdivider shall enter into an agreement with the village
containing a restriction upon the plat whereby the Administrator shall not be
permitted to issue a building permit for any structure upon any lot within the
subdivision until the improvements, as specified in this section, have been
completed, or satisfactory arrangements have been made with the village for the
completion of such improvements. Such plat restrictions shall be made a part of
all deeds or contracts for any lot within the subdivision.
(`94 Code, § 1133.07) 
Penalty, see § 153.999
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
§ 153.095  RESPONSIBILITIES OF PLANNING COMMISSION AND ADMINISTRATOR.
   These Subdivision Regulations shall be administered and enforced by the
Planning Commission and the Village Administrator. Such rules and procedures as
are necessary to carry out the provisions of these Subdivision Regulations may
be adopted by the Commission and the Administrator.
(`94 Code, § 1123.01)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.096  CONSULTATIONS OF SUBDIVIDER WITH VILLAGE.
   It is recommended that the subdivider or his or her engineer consult with
the Village Administrator while a subdivision plan is still in sketch form and
before the preliminary plat is prepared, to acquaint himself or herself with
village ordinances, planned projects and performance bond and contract
requirements.
(`94 Code, § 1123.02)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.097  RECORDING OF PLATS; APPROVAL REQUIRED.
   No plat of any subdivision shall be recorded with the county or have any
validity until approved in the manner prescribed in these Subdivision
Regulations.
(`94 Code, § 1123.03)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.098  SALES PROHIBITED PRIOR TO TENTATIVE APPROVAL.
   No person proposing to make or having made a subdivision within the
territorial jurisdiction of these Subdivision Regulations shall make any
contract for the sale of, or offer to sell, a subdivision or any part thereof,
or proceed with any construction work on the proposed subdivision, including
grading, which may affect the arrangement of streets, until such person has
obtained from the Planning Commission and Council tentative approval of the
proposed subdivision.
(`94 Code, § 1123.04)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.099  ISSUANCE OF PERMITS.
   No permit required for any work in connection with any subdivision shall be
issued until the plat therefor has been approved and recorded as prescribed in
these Subdivision Regulations and until house numbers have been assigned by the
village. Such house numbers shall be placed on each unit in a conspicuous
location acceptable to the Post Office Department.
(`94 Code, § 1123.05)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.100  WITHHOLDING OF PUBLIC SERVICES.
   The village shall withhold all public services of any nature, including the
maintenance of streets and the furnishing of sewage facilities and water
service, from all subdivisions which have not been approved and from all areas
dedicated to the public which have not been accepted by the Planning Commission
and Council in the manner prescribed in these Subdivision Regulations.
(`94 Code, § 1123.06)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.101  INSPECTION COSTS.
   The subdivider shall reimburse the village for the costs, to the village, of
inspecting and checking of water and sewer facility installations and street
construction by village personnel or personnel hired by the village.
(`94 Code, § 1123.07)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.102  PLAT FILING FEE.
   The minimum filing fee for a subdivision plat shall be $20 per acre.
(`94 Code, § 1123.08)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.103  SUBDIVISIONS OF FIVE LOTS OR LESS.
   (A)   When a proposed subdivision of land involves five lots or less and
does not require the opening, widening or extension of any street, it may be
submitted to the Planning Commission for approval without a plat, provided,
however, that a cumulative total of not more than five lots shall be permitted
on one parcel of land without a plat.
   (B)   A drawing based upon a survey showing the location of the property and
giving dimensions and other such information as may be necessary and a legal
description in writing must be submitted with the request.
   (C)   When the existing street right-of-way width is inadequate, a right-of-
way conveyance by deed shall be made by the owner to satisfy the deficiency.
Such dedication shall be made to the village when the land in question is
within the corporate limits or to the county when it is within the three-mile
area of jurisdiction. The grantor shall not be required to install street
improvements as a condition of conveyance.
   (D)   Upon receipt of the drawing, legal description and right-of-way
conveyance, if required, the Planning Commission shall determine to its
satisfaction that the proposed lot split is not contrary to any applicable
platting, subdividing or zoning regulations, and if no conflict exists it shall
approve the lot split.
(`94 Code, § 1123.09)  (Ord. 17-70, passed 9-22-70)
§ 153.104  BUILDING PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE SCHEDULE.
   (A)   Required.  No building shall be erected, converted, enlarged,
demolished, reconstructed, moved or structurally altered without first
obtaining, from the Village Administrator, a building permit and the payment of

§ 153.999  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of these Subdivision Regulations shall be fined not
less than $5 nor more than $100. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. The owner of any
buildings or premises or parts thereof, that are in violation of these
Regulations and any architect, building contractor, agent or person employed in
connection therewith and who may have assisted in the commission of any such
violation shall be guilty of a separate offense.
(`94 Code, § 1123.99)  (Ord. 19-84, passed 8-14-84)
